p: Polyphenols, flavonoids, proanthocyanidins, saponins, monoterpenoids, triterpenoids, glucosides, sesquiterpenes, and alkaloids isolated from various medicinal plants have diverse antiviral activities of which some are listed in Table 1. Antiviral drugs interact with haemagglutinin, which interferes with the entry of the virus. Neuraminidase, an essential glycoprotein required for viral amplification (proliferation and infections), catalyzes the cleavage of α‐(2,3) or α‐(2,6) ketosidic linkage between sialic acid and oligosaccharide of glycoproteins such that viruses release from infectious cells (Muchtaridi, Sugijanto, Mohd Gazzali, & Wahab, 2020). Neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs) can block the viral enzyme neuraminidase, which prevents the release of viruses from host cells (Liao, Kowal, Cardenas, & Beauchemin, 2017). There is a strong matching between Query sequence H1N1 neurominidase and SARS‐CoV‐2 Orf 3a. Friedeline ( 42), methyl‐3α,23‐dihydroxy‐17,14‐friedolanstan‐8,14,24‐trien‐26‐oat ( 43), 24E‐3a,9,23‐trihydroxy‐17,14‐ friedolanostan‐14,24‐dien‐26‐oate ( 44) (Figure 2d), and catechin ( 10) (Figure 2d) isolated from Garcinia celebica L. leaves extract areneuraminidase inhibitors, which bind to active amino acid residues of neuraminidase by hydrogen bonds and van der Waals force and interfere virus release from host cells (Muchtaridi et al., 2020).
